RMPDescription: Resubmission for Removal of TMOA Process

_chemical.ChemicalName: Oleum (Fuming Sulfuric acid)  [Sulfuric acid, mixture with sulfur trioxide]

_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Pesticide and Other Agricultural Chemical Manufacturing
Pesticide and Other Agricultural Chemical Manufacturing

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
FMC CORPORATION
AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS GROUP
BALTIMORE, MARYLAND


EXECUTIVE SUMMARY


In an effort to proactively inform the community of changes occurring at the facility, the FMC Corporation, Agricultural Products Group (APG) Baltimore Plant has prepared this revised Risk Management Plan (RMP) for resubmission to the EPA.  This is the Baltimore Plant's second revision since the original submission date in June 1999.  The changes incorporated in this revision reflect the removal of a previously reported process and its associated chemical inventory.  The Baltimore Plant no longer manufactures trimethyl orthoacetate (TMOA) and as a result, the inventory of anhydrous hydrogen chloride (AHCl) stored onsite has decreased substantially.  This reduction in chemical inventory changes the plant's worst-case toxic release scenario reported previously.  This means that AHCl is no longer available onsite in sufficient quantity to represent the plant's worst-case scenario for the release of a toxic chemical, as defined in the EPA's guidelines.  The new scenario, involving chlorine, is presented in this revised RMP.

The FMC APG Baltimore Plant manufacturing facility is committed to protecting the safety and health of employees, contractors, customers, the surrounding community and the environment.  Furthermore, it is committed to conducting business in a manner that is compatible with the balanced environmental needs of the community in which it operates. This commitment requires compliance with all applicable laws and regulations, facilities that are designed and operated to high standards, and systematic identification and management of safety, health, and environmental risks. 

In keeping with this commitment, the FMC APG Baltimore Plant has established a comprehensive Safety Management System that strives to identify and eliminate potential exposures that include, but are not limited to, personal injury/illness, property damage, fires, process incidents, and breaches of se

curity. 

The Safety Management System embodies and employs the spirit and intent of the concepts found in the American Chemistry Council's (ACC's) Responsible Care Initiative, the OSHA Process Safety Management Standard, the EPA's Risk Management Program Rule, and the FMC Corporate Safety and Industrial Hygiene Policies and Strategies. 

The Safety Management System includes the following Safety Policy statement:

"We are all personally responsible, at the Baltimore Plant, to take the necessary steps to eliminate or reduce exposure to accidental injury and conditions that may adversely affect our health and safety.  No job is so important that we cannot take time to perform our work safely." 
 
The Safety Management System also includes the following Process Safety Vision statement:

"The employees at FMC Baltimore are dedicated to developing, implementing and operating sound process safety programs, maintaining compliance with both internal FMC and external requirements, improving process safety program performance using a risk-benefit approach, and addressing process safety and risk management issues and concerns in a timely manner.

FMC Baltimore is fully committed to the Responsible Care initiatives: Process Safety, Employee Safety and Health, Distribution, Pollution Prevention, Community Awareness and Emergency Response (CAER), and Product Stewardship.

FMC Baltimore achieves compliance with Responsible Care codes through workplace health and safety programs as well as release and waste generation reduction programs.  These programs ensure that FMC Baltimore is operated in a manner that protects the environment and the health and safety of personnel and the public."

The management of the FMC APG Baltimore Plant has authorized specific risk management-related programs and activities in compliance with EPA's Risk Management Program ruling (40 CFR Part 68).  These activities include the assessment of the potential hazards associated with processes that handle or

store more than a threshold quantity of substances regulated by the EPA.  Additional programs are in effect to prevent the accidental release of these hazardous substances and to effectively respond to an emergency if a release does occur.


The FMC Corporation, Agricultural Products Group Baltimore Plant 

The Baltimore Plant produces herbicides and pesticides for use in products providing crop protection and pest control.  The plant's end products are shipped offsite for formulation and distribution to external users.  The processes covered by the EPA's Risk Management Program requirements at this facility include the Sulfentrazone Process, MAC (methallyl chloride) Process, and the Clomazone Process.

The Sulfentrazone Process includes the regulated chemicals chlorine (CAS Number 007782-50-5), nitric acid (CAS Number 007697-37-2), oleum (CAS Number 008014-95-7), and acetaldehyde (CAS Number 000075-07-0).  The MAC Process includes the regulated chemicals chlorine (CAS Number 007782-50-5) and isobutylene (CAS Number 000115-11-7).  The Clomazone Process includes the regulated chemical anhydrous hydrogen chloride (CAS Number 007647-01-0). 


Worst-Case Release Scenarios

RMP regulations for Program 3 processes require performing a consequence analysis for one worst-case release scenario that results in the greatest distance, in any direction, to a toxic endpoint value established by the Emergency Response Planning Guideline (ERPG-2).  The toxic endpoint is an estimate of the maximum possible area that could potentially be affected in the unlikely event of a worst-case release.  The endpoint represents the maximum airborne chemical concentration below which it is believed that nearly all individuals could be exposed for up to one hour without serious health effects or symptoms that could impair their abilities to take protective action.  A worst-case scenario must also be performed for the flammable substance having the greatest potential for offsite impacts.  The wor

st-case scenarios presented in this document were chosen based on a comparison of the potential hazards associated with each of the regulated chemicals present onsite.  The assumptions required for the analysis of worst-case scenarios are very conservative and, therefore, provide conservative results.

Toxic Worst-Case Scenario: Chlorine in the MAC and Sulfentrazone Processes
The worst-case release scenario selected for the plant's toxic materials was the complete loss of the contents of one full chlorine railcar.  The release scenario assumed the loss of 180,000 pounds of chlorine through a toxic gas release occurring over 10 minutes. The distance to the toxic endpoint established for chlorine (0.0087 mg/l) is approximately 14.0 miles under this worst-case scenario.  Public receptors identified include residences, institutions (schools, hospitals, prisons), parks and recreational areas, and major commercial, office and industrial buildings. 

Flammable Worst-Case Scenario: Isobutylene in the MAC Process
The worst-case release scenario selected for the RMP-regulated flammable substances assumes the complete loss of the entire contents of the plant's isobutylene storage vessel with a subsequent vapor cloud explosion.  The release scenario assumes that the vessel is filled to the maximum permissible level and contains approximately 210,000 pounds of isobutylene.  Administrative controls at the plant limit the maximum quantity of isobutylene in the vessel to this amount.  The distance to the endpoint (1 psi overpressure) reached by the event is estimated to be 0.5 miles.  The residential population estimated for the affected area, as obtained from census data, is 0.  Public receptors identified include major commercial, office and industrial buildings.


Alternative Release Scenarios

RMP regulations require that at least one alternative release scenario be identified and analyzed for each regulated toxic chemical present.  Scenarios considered more realistic than the

worst-case scenario were selected to represent the alternative releases for each of the toxic materials.  In addition, one alternative case scenario was developed to represent the regulated flammables at the site. 

Alternative Scenario Toxics: Chlorine in the Sulfentrazone and MAC Processes
The alternative release scenario developed for chlorine assumes the failure of a transfer line during transfer of the chemical from a rail car.  Safety systems in place to minimize the release include chlorine detectors, excess flow valves, a water deluge system, and an emergency shutdown.  The estimated distance to the toxic endpoint (0.0087 mg/L) was found to be 0.4 miles.  The residential population estimated for the affected area, as obtained from census data, is 0.  Public receptors identified include major commercial, office and industrial buildings.  

Alternative Scenario Toxics: Nitric Acid in the Sulfentrazone Process
The alternative release scenario developed for nitric acid assumes the failure of a transfer line during transfer of the chemical from a tank truck.  Excess flow valves are in place as a safety system to minimize the quantity of material released.  The estimated distance to the toxic endpoint (0.0260 mg/L) was found to be 0.2 miles.  The residential population estimated for the affected area, as obtained from census data, is 0.  Public receptors identified include major commercial, office and industrial buildings. 

Alternative Scenario Toxics: Oleum in the Sulfentrazone Process
The alternative release scenario developed for oleum assumes the failure of a transfer line during the transfer of the chemical from a tank truck.  Safety systems in place to minimize the release include oleum detectors, excess flow valves, and an emergency shutdown.  The estimated distance to the toxic endpoint (0.0100 mg/L) was found to be 0.2 miles.  The residential population estimated for the affected area, as obtained from census data, is 0.  Public receptors identified incl

ude major commercial, office and industrial buildings. 

Alternative Scenario Toxics: Anhydrous Hydrogen Chloride in the Clomazone Process
The alternative release scenario developed for anhydrous hydrogen chloride assumes the failure of a transfer line during transfer of the chemical from a tube trailer.  Safety systems in place to minimize the release include hydrogen chloride detectors, excess flow valves and an emergency shutdown.  The estimated distance to the toxic endpoint (0.0300 mg/L) was found to be 0.1 miles.  The residential population estimated for the affected area, as obtained from census data, is 0.  Public receptors identified include major commercial, office and industrial buildings. 

Alternative Scenario Flammables: Isobutylene in the MAC Process
The alternative release scenario developed for the flammables assumes the failure of a transfer line on an isobutylene rail car during transfer of the chemical and a subsequent vapor cloud fire.  Safety systems in place to minimize the release include excess flow valves, a water deluge system and an emergency shutdown system.  The distance to the endpoint was found to be less than 0.1 miles.  The residential population estimated for the affected area, as obtained from census data is 0.  Public receptors identified include major commercial, office and industrial buildings. 


Accidental Release Prevention Program

To prevent and mitigate accidental releases of chemicals, FMC Baltimore has implemented several precautionary measures.  These measures include process and equipment controls, operating procedures, preventive maintenance programs, safe work practices, employee training, and audit programs.  In addition, all process equipment and systems are designed and constructed in accordance with recognized chemical industry codes and standards.

The Baltimore Plant has developed and implemented a comprehensive Process Safety Management (PSM) program covering the storage, use and handling of the plant's chemi

cals.  As part of this program, the plant's processes are periodically evaluated to analyze all of the potential hazards associated with each process, including the potential to release chemicals. 

The Baltimore Plant has also developed Standard Operating Procedures governing all employees and contractors that work in the facility.  These procedures incorporate safety measures to prevent employee injury, equipment damage, and accidental releases.  Additional Safe Work Procedures have also been developed to address the hazards associated with specific work activities performed in the plant.  Safety committees, consisting of personnel from all plant disciplines, periodically evaluate the procedures and perform behavior-based safety observations to monitor implementation.

FMC Baltimore understands that maintaining the plant's process equipment in good working order is essential for the prevention of accidental releases and has accordingly developed and implemented a preventive maintenance program.  This program is scheduled, documented and managed to ensure that process equipment, and their associated systems, are maintained in a safe operating condition.  Routine inspections are performed and equipment checklists are used to provide advanced notice of potential maintenance and repair needs.

To ensure that the control measures at the Baltimore Plant are effective in maintaining the safe operation of the plant, regularly scheduled compliance audits are performed.  In accordance with the PSM program and FMC's corporate requirements, comprehensive Process Safety and Risk Management Program audits are conducted by an outside team of experts every three years.  In addition, the facilities and records of the Baltimore Plant are periodically inspected and audited by the following agencies and organizations:

The Maryland State Occupational Safety and Health Program (MOSH)
The Maryland State Department of the Environment (MDE)
The Baltimore City Fire Department (BCFD)
The U

nited States Coast Guard (USCG)
Factory Mutual

In addition, loss prevention and risk management audits are conducted by outside organizations for plant insurance purposes.


Five-Year Accident History 

During the five years immediately prior to the date of this report, no accidental releases meeting the reporting requirements for this RMP were experienced at the Baltimore Plant.  However, there were two minor releases of chlorine and one minor release of nitric acid during this time.  Each of these releases resulted in on-plant first aid attention only.  There were no impacts to the environment or the surrounding community since all of the releases remained within the plant boundaries.


Emergency Response Program 

The FMC Baltimore Plant has a multi-faceted Emergency Management Program for response to the various types and magnitudes of emergencies that could potentially occur at the facility.  The program addresses all aspects of emergency response and consists of several elements including:

1) A written Emergency Response Plan developed specifically for the hazards and potential emergencies that may occur at the plant.

2) Coordination of the plan with the Local Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC).

3) An onsite Emergency Response Brigade trained and equipped to respond to chemical releases, fires, and medical emergencies.

4) An onsite Incident Command System to direct the Emergency Response Brigade and act as the liaison with outside response agencies.

5) Training and drills conducted jointly with local and state agencies including the Baltimore City Fire Department (LEPC).

6) Coordination of the Emergency Management Program with the South Baltimore Industrial Mutual Aid Program (SBIMAP), an area-wide organization sharing response equipment, supplies and expertise among its members, including assistance to Fire Departments dealing with non-member emergencies.


Continuous Improvement

As part of the Baltimore Plant's efforts to continuously improve the o

perations of the facility, several changes are planned to improve safety and further reduce the potential for a release of hazardous chemicals.  Some of these changes are currently underway and several others including equipment upgrades, additional preventive maintenance procedures and additional safety systems are planned for implementation over the course of the next year.
